title: Course Guide
body: This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.
subtitle: Course Organization and FAQs
pageBody:
Welcome to the online course "The Limits to Growth â€“ Sustainability and the Circular Economy". The ETCE Lab is teaching this course at the Technical University of Clausthal. 

This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.

title: Sustainable Everyday Practices
body: Throughout this module, we will delve into examples of sustainable everyday practices, discuss why it is crucial to embrace sustainable practices in your everyday life and explore the differences between individual and corporate sustainability.
pageBody:
Throughout this module, we will delve into various examples of sustainable everyday practices. By exploring these examples, you will gain a comprehensive understanding of how small actions in your daily life can contribute to a more sustainable world. Moreover, we will discuss the reasons why it is crucial to embrace sustainable practices in your everyday life. Furthermore, we will explore the differences between individual and corporate sustainability. While individuals have the power to make choices and take actions in their personal lives, corporations have a larger scale and influence in driving sustainable change.

By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive overview of sustainable everyday practices, (hopefully) be inspired by examples of how you can make a difference, understand the reasons to act more sustainably in your everyday life, and recognize the distinct roles and respobsibilities of individuals and corporations in promoting sustainability.

title: Course Organization
body: Find out who the team organising the course is, how the course is structured and what the formal requirements for successful participation are.
subtitle: Wintersemester 2023/24

title: Introduction
body: In this chapter, you will find out what the central concept behind the course is. We will give you a short overview of the ecological problems and societal challenges that we will discuss during the course.
pageBody:
In this chapter, you will discover the central concept behind the course. We will give you a short overview of the ecological problems and societal challenges we will discuss and why we think this may be of more importance to you than you may first think. 

Below, you can find the lecture recording and the slides for this lecture. By clicking on the links, you will be redirected to the video server of the TU Clausthal and our publicly available teaching material on GitHub.

title: Food Waste and Foodsharing
body: In the following section, you will learn more about one specific sustainable practice: foodsharing. What exactly is foodsharing, how does it work and how can you share food with others or get food that others are willing to share.
pageBody:
Food waste has become a global predicament of alarming proportions, capturing the attention of individuals, organizations, and policymakers worldwide. Each year, a staggering amount of food is needlessly discarded, exacerbating issues of hunger, environmental degradation, and economic inefficiency. This growing crisis demands immediate attention and concerted efforts from all sectors of society to tackle the multifaceted challenges it presents.

Throughout this segment, we will take a closer look at the scale at which food is being wasted worldwide on a daily basis. We will scrutinize some of the underlying reasons as to why is food being needlessly thrown away and talk about the the far-reaching economic, environmental and social implications of food waste. Moreover, it is also important to take a look possible solutions both on the political level as well as on an individual level. By looking at foodsharing as a local and self-organized practice, we want to point out a practical pathway to saving food and living more sustainably.

title: Massive Open Online Course (MOOC)
body: Find out what a MOOC is and how we will use asynchronous learning, pre-recorded videos and interactive content in this course.
subtitle: A Look Behind the Scenes
pageBody:
The ETCE Lab at Clausthal University of Technology has been creating MOOC content for the course "Limits to Growth â€“ Sustainability and the Circular Economy" since March 2023. We are still working on expanding and improving the course and are thankful for your feedback. 

In this chapter, we will give you further insights into what exactly a Massive Open Online Course is and how we produce the interactive and asynchronous content for this course.

title: Challenges I
body: Climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues of our time, affecting ecosystems, economies, and societies worldwide. In this chapter, we will explore the science, impacts, and causes of climate change, emphasizing its profound implications for sustainability.
subtitle: Climate Change
pageBody: Climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues of our time, affecting ecosystems, economies, and societies worldwide. In this chapter, we will explore the science, impacts, and causes of climate change, emphasizing its profound implications for sustainability. As we delve into the complexities of this global challenge, we'll also examine strategies, policies, and individual actions aimed at mitigating its effects and building a resilient, sustainable future.

title: L00 - Organization
body: Here you can find the live lecture recording explaining how the course is organised and the lecture slides of the current semester.
subtitle: Lecture Recording and Slides
pageBody: Here you can find the live lecture recording explaining how the course is organised and the lecture slides of the current semester.

title: Challenges II
body: Our planet faces an alarming convergence of environmental degradation, resource depletion, and escalating social and political tensions. In this session, we will unravel the intricate connections between these challenges, exploring how pollution and resource scarcity amplify social disparities and spark political instability.
subtitle: Environmental Pollution and Dwindling Natural Ressources
pageBody: Our planet faces an alarming convergence of environmental degradation, resource depletion, and escalating social and political tensions. In this session, we will unravel the intricate connections between these challenges, exploring how pollution and resource scarcity amplify social disparities and spark political instability.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
body: You can find a collection of the most frequently asked questions regarding the organization of the course, requirements for students and the exam here.
pageBody: You can find a collection of the most frequently asked questions regarding the organization of the course, requirements for students and the exam here.

title: Sustainability and Political (In-)Action
body: In this chapter, we will discuss different understandings and definitions of sustainability and sustainable development. Additionally, we will examine the dynamic interplay between political and social actors in addressing and delaying actions to fight urgent global challenges.
pageBody: In this chapter, we will discuss different understandings and definitions of sustainability and sustainable development. Additionally, we will examine the dynamic interplay between political and social actors in addressing the urgent global challenge of climate change. We will explore the actions and inactions of governments, organisations, and individuals in shaping climate policies, influencing public opinion, and driving change.

title: Limits to Growth and Planetary Boundaries
displayTitle: Limits to Growth and Planetary Boundaries
body: In this chater, we will explore the critical concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries that shape our understanding of sustainable development.
pageBody:
In this chater, we will explore the critical concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries that shape our understanding of sustainable development.

As our planet faces escalating environmental challenges, it is essential to grasp the constraints within which our societies must operate to ensure a viable future. Join us as we delve into the interconnected issues of resource depletion, climate change, biodiversity loss, and the imperative of staying within Earth's ecological boundaries for a more sustainable and resilient world.

title: Life Cycle Assessement
body: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts.
pageBody: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts. From raw material extraction to disposal, LCAs provide insights into resource use, emissions, and energy consumption, aiding in informed decision-making for a more sustainable future.

title: Circular Economy
body: As we confront the challenges of resource depletion and waste accumulation, the concept of a circular economy emerges as a transformative solution. In this chapter, we will delve into the main characteristics of a circular economy, where products and materials are reused, refurbished, remanufactured, and recycled, reducing waste and environmental impact.
pageBody: As we confront the challenges of resource depletion and waste accumulation, the concept of a circular economy emerges as a transformative solution. In this chapter, we will delve into the main characteristics of a circular economy, where products and materials are reused, refurbished, remanufactured, and recycled, reducing waste and environmental impact.

title: Beyond the Circular Economy
body: While the circular economy is a critical step, we'll now venture into advanced strategies that push the boundaries of sustainability. Our focus will be on economic models that reimagine consumption, production, and finance. We will explore innovative approaches that prioritize people and the planet over profit, aiming to create a harmonious, prosperous, and sustainable world.
pageBody: While the circular economy is a critical step, we'll now venture into advanced strategies that push the boundaries of sustainability. Our focus will be on economic models that reimagine consumption, production, and finance. We will explore innovative approaches that prioritize people and the planet over profit, aiming to create a harmonious, prosperous, and sustainable world.

title: Towards a Circular Society
body: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation. We'll explore how circular thinking can reshape governance, education, and community dynamics, ultimately envisioning a world where human well-being and environmental health coexist harmoniously.
pageBody: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation. We'll explore how circular thinking can reshape governance, education, and community dynamics, ultimately envisioning a world where human well-being and environmental health coexist harmoniously.

title: Technologies and What They (Can) Not Do
displayTitle: Technologies and What They (Can) Not Do
body: Sustainable innovations can potentially drive positive change, from renewable energy to efficient transportation. Yet, it's essential to acknowledge their limitations. In this chapter, we will scrutinise the boundaries of technology, emphasising the need for holistic approaches that encompass social, economic, and behavioural aspects to achieve genuine sustainability.
pageBody: Sustainable innovations can potentially drive positive change, from renewable energy to efficient transportation. Yet, it's essential to acknowledge their limitations. While technology can mitigate some environmental challenges, it's not a one-size-fits-it-all solution. We'll scrutinise the boundaries of technology, emphasising the need for holistic approaches that encompass social, economic, and behavioural aspects to achieve genuine sustainability. By understanding the possibilities and constraints, we can chart a more effective course toward a sustainable future.

title: Conclusion
body: In this course, we have explored the nuances of environmental, social, and economic sustainability, recognizing their interplay. Throughout our discussions, we've discovered that sustainable solutions demand collaborative efforts, innovative thinking, and a commitment to change.
pageBody: In this course, we have explored the nuances of environmental, social, and economic sustainability, recognizing their interplay. Throughout our discussions, we've discovered that sustainable solutions demand collaborative efforts, innovative thinking, and a commitment to change.
